title: Engineering typeface?
content:
I’m doing an article on the engineering department of my local university. What is a good display face that communicates “engineering?” I’ve seen one that was outlined, visible rules for baseline, xheight, etc, and visible circles used to determine the geometry of the typeface. Now I can’t find it and my searches on the font websites is coming up short. Any ides?

Thanks,  
Scott
author: yahooboy

comments.content: you have somewhat of an [overdesigned typeface](http://web.archive.org/web/20051111043715/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/scriptorium/draughtwork) that matches your description, besides the usual Leonardo.

Draughtwork is close, but a little too much (don’t need the grid)! “Overdesigned” will work because I’m only using two letters (UT). The Leonardo I have on my machine is a handwritten font. Maybe I only have one of the family?

Since I am only using two letters, I may just pick a geometric typeface and add the embelishments myself. Thought it’d be simple if I could just use a typeface though.

if you only need two letters, do you have, or can you get hold of any rotring/technical lettering stencils? you could do the lettering yourself, and scan it in. you’d then get a more ‘authentic’ feel to the lettering as well…

Try Dispatch and Stainless from Font Bureau.

Héctor

Maybe you’re thinking of the Albrecht Dürer stuff.

[http://www.myfonts.com/fonts/ihof/p22-durer-caps/](http://web.archive.org/web/20051111043715/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/ihof/p22-durer-caps/)

I bet you’re thinking of Rubino:  
 [http://www.fonts.com/findfonts/mondosearchresults.htm?st=12&kid=rubino](http://web.archive.org/web/20051111043715/http:/www.fonts.com/findfonts/mondosearchresults.htm?st=12&kid=rubino)

hhp
